I'm on a grandfathered unlimited data plan from Verizon. But I refuse to change my phone for anything. Because I only have two phones on my account, one is a family member who has 0 usage for data or anything else. I also don't have use for it because I already have Wi Fi at home, don't use a tablet.

This is little more than smoke and mirrors. Only reason why I've not fired Verizon is because their coverage is actually better where I live.

Unbelievably generous of you to cede the man his status as a human being in spite of his unseemly whining, particularly in view of the fact that you, apparently, have never whined or rendered an unduly harsh judgment in your life.

Every normal person I know, poor or otherwise, complains from time-to-time. We can now add Anetliner Netliner to the list. What is interesting is when someone (like Douthat) does so insightfully -- whether I agree with their politics or not.

On the other hand, the tired online complaint we inevitably see posted any time a reporter or writer who isn't poor complains -- not very interesting or insightful. We've all heard that point before: it's preachy, overly-simplistic, and basically a conversation-ender (except for those who qualify as "undeserving poor" I guess).
And less self pity.

This vote again undermines the idea that "card check" is a true representation of worker preferences. In a "card check," the union reps go one-on-one with the workers, and the workers know that the unions guys can give them payback if they refuse to sign. When the same workers get a chance to register their true preferences in private, without anyone else knowing how they vote, they turn against the union. Your comment about D being a passing grade reminds of Nigel Tufner of Spinal Tap, thinking he's got one up on volume because his amp goes up to 11.

"D" is an arbitrary convention, indicating that although you have not performed less than average, but you have mastered enough of the material to not have to repeat the course. A "D" to me makes perfect sense in the bell distribution sense.

In some schools, "D" is not actually a passing grade. Where I went to college, if you received a "D" in a subject in your major field, it would not count as credit toward your major, and you were "encouraged" to pursue another field.

Personally I felt the title of the puzzle was misleading in the portrayal that a D is a passing grade. Definitely an interesting statement on our education system. That said, it should be recognized that creating a puzzle of this scope is no small feat and Yaakov deserves an A for his efforts.

I don't really understand where this is coming from. It says KJ is the author, but I'm sure it's not about her family, so who is this person?

I know lots of people who live on wages like these. I see them in the food bank where I'm on the board and at the animal sanctuary where I volunteer. And they are our neighbors and the families of kids in my husband's class. Life for them can be so precarious.

One family brought in an elderly cat that was obviously sick, very skinny. They could not afford to take her to the vet for a diagnosis or even to have her put down, so relinquished her to the sanctuary. The teenage daughter, who didn't remember life without this pet, was in tears, the mom barely holding up. So sad. (A vet looked at her and diagnosed hyperthyroidism; she will soon return to her home.)

My heart goes out to everyone who finds herself in such dire straights.

@octavian. The vast majority of people in the US are not familiar with the auto industry, and as such, unions writ large (not simply the UAW) take almost complete blame for the "destruction" of the industry.

The reality, as always, is more complicated and complex. The fact is that it what most wrecked the US auto industry were Big Three corporate management decisions that ignored global competition and continued to build inefficient, gas-guzzling vehicles that fewer consumers wanted over time, something that Patrick mentioned below.

Unions had nothing to do with those decisions.

The bottom line to a solid bottom line is that business must offer products the consumers want and, for years, very poor Big Three management decisions led to very poor products. Interestingly, the successful German model shows that unions are integral to industrial decision making along with corporate management and other community stakeholders. This pro-union model has given most German auto workers a better standard of living, more say in work rules, and better products than their non-union (and even some union) counterparts in the US.

Wake me when these fusion "breakthrough" folks have a 5 MW electric generator pilot plant up and running.

Until then, I think I'll hang on to my shares in Exxon and Chevron.
